jparsec.ephem

Enum EphemerisElement.OBSERVING_WAVELENGTH

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Enum<EphemerisElement.OBSERVING_WAVELENGTH>
      • jparsec.ephem.EphemerisElement.OBSERVING_WAVELENGTH
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<EphemerisElement.OBSERVING_WAVELENGTH>
    Enclosing class:
    EphemerisElement

    public static enum EphemerisElement.OBSERVING_WAVELENGTH
extends java.lang.Enum<EphemerisElement.OBSERVING_WAVELENGTH>
    The different set of observing wavelengths. This will affect objects positions corrected by refraction.

    • Enum Constant Summary

      Enum Constants 
      Enum Constant and Description
      NUMERICAL_INTEGRATION
      Calculates refraction for a given zenith distance and wavelength using the Hohenkerk and Sinclair method (NAO Technical Notes 59 and 63), slightly modified to account for refraction at radio wavelengths.
      OPTICAL_BENNET
      Optical wavelengths.
      OPTICAL_YAN
      Optical wavelengths.
      RADIO_BENNET
      Similar formulae as the Bennet for optical, but with parameters adapted to Yebes observatory at radio wavelengths.
      RADIO_YAN
      Radio wavelengths.

    • Enum Constant Detail

      • OPTICAL_BENNET

        public static final EphemerisElement.OBSERVING_WAVELENGTH OPTICAL_BENNET
        Optical wavelengths. Default value, Bennet (1982) formulae for refraction will be used. Classical formulae commonly used, but less accurate. See Journal of Navigation (Royal Institute) 35, 255-259, and also Explanatory Supplement to the Astronomical Almanac, p. 144. This formula is used for observed elevations between -4 and 90 deg.

      • RADIO_BENNET

        public static final EphemerisElement.OBSERVING_WAVELENGTH RADIO_BENNET
        Similar formulae as the Bennet for optical, but with parameters adapted to Yebes observatory at radio wavelengths.

      • OPTICAL_YAN

        public static final EphemerisElement.OBSERVING_WAVELENGTH OPTICAL_YAN
        Optical wavelengths. Yan (1996) formulae for refraction will be used, with an accuracy of 0.3". See also Magnum (2001), ALMA Memorandum 366, and the corrections/comments by NRAO at https://safe.nrao.edu/wiki/pub/Main/RefBendDelayCalc/RefBendDelayCalc.pdf. The observing wavelength in microns can be set in the corresponding variable of the enum constant, in case a value different from 0.555 microns is desired. This formula is used for observed elevations between -1 and 90 deg.

      • RADIO_YAN

        public static final EphemerisElement.OBSERVING_WAVELENGTH RADIO_YAN
        Radio wavelengths. Yan (1996) formulae for refraction will be used, with an accuracy of 0.3" below 100 GHz. See also Magnum (2001), ALMA Memorandum 366. Frequency range is from the GHz regime to the THz. Maximum error comparing with the atmospheric model by Liebe (1996) for ALMA site is 2% at 500 GHz, and it is around 1% for nu > 300 GHz. Between 100 and 300 GHz the error is only 0.5%. This formula is used for observed elevations between -1 and 90 deg.

      • NUMERICAL_INTEGRATION

        public static final EphemerisElement.OBSERVING_WAVELENGTH NUMERICAL_INTEGRATION
        Calculates refraction for a given zenith distance and wavelength using the Hohenkerk and Sinclair method (NAO Technical Notes 59 and 63), slightly modified to account for refraction at radio wavelengths. The method is a Java implementation of the one present in the SLALIB package. This method should be more accurate than any of the others, but also requires more calculations.

    • Field Detail

      • observingWavelength

        public double observingWavelength
        Defines the observing wavelength for the source. This affects the Yan formulae in the optical refraction case, which is designed to drop some terms for 0.532 microns, although the eye has its maximum sensitivity in 0.555 microns. Default value is 0.555 microns. In radio wavelengths refraction is independent from frequency. This value also affects the refraction for the numerical integration option. In case wavelength is greater than 100 microns the algorithm is adapted to account for refraction in radio wavelengths.
